Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the World Health Organization (WHO) did not issue any advisory against eating cabbage during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or official statement from the WHO to support the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the coronavirus stays in cabbage for a longer duration compared to other objects, which is not supported by any scientific evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that there is no basis for the claim and it is false. The CDC states that there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with food.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the potential risk of consuming cabbage during the pandemic by stating that the virus lasts more than 30 hours on cabbage, without any factual basis.
Understate: There is no understatement bias present in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by spreading misinformation and false information about the WHO's stance on eating cabbage during the pandemic.
